ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] proxy's and PUT
ygData.msgSnippet: I m going to guess that a cache that sees a PUT will be able to return that data, and when it sees a DELETE it can remove the entry. If you use a different

I'm going to guess that a cache that sees a PUT will be able to return
that data, and when it sees a DELETE it can remove the entry.
If you use a different method with a different resource ID, I doubt
the cache can do it's thing.

But maybe not - caching is always more subtle than I think.


 On 11/20/06, Mike Schinkel <mikeschinkel@...> wrote:
>
>
> Mark Baker  wrote:
> >> Another alternative would be to use a subordinate URI
>  >>  (e.g. POST http://example.org/foo/bar  does the equivalent of PUT  to
> >>  http://example.org/foo), but that screw up  caches.
>
> Why does that screw up  caches?  I thought only GET was cachable?
>
>
> -Mike Schinkel
> http://www.mikeschinkel.com/blogs/
> http://www.welldesignedurls.org/
